expectations:
- MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese (teaching Japanese)
      - Should include dedicated chapters for writing systems (hiragana, katakana, kanji)
      - Should cover Japanese-specific grammar (particles, verb forms, honorifics, counters)
      - Should cover vocabulary themes and communication scenarios

      
  - Chapters should follow CEFR progression from A1 (beginner) to C2 (mastery)
  - ALL chapters must be content-domain chapters: grammar structures, vocabulary themes, or communication scenarios
  - NO skill-based chapters (pronunciation, listening, reading, writing) — those skills are built into every lesson automatically
  - NO culture chapters (history, traditions, cuisine, music, festivals, customs)
  - NO career or professional chapters (business language, workplace communication)
  - NO proficiency exam preparation chapters (DELE, JLPT, DELF, HSK, etc.)
  - NO literature or media chapters (books, films, songs, poetry)
  - Should cover grammar structures (verb tenses, nouns, articles, etc.) and vocabulary themes (food, travel, health, etc.)
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Titles should be concise, no filler words
  - Descriptions should be concise, no fluff (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises

rankings.reasoning: Model D provides the most comprehensive and well-structured curriculum with 120 chapters. It excellently covers all Japanese-specific requirements: separate hiragana/katakana chapters with diacritics and combinations, kanji sections by semantic fields with composites and irregular readings, thorough particle coverage, all verb forms (potential, passive, causative, causative-passive), honorifics (sonkeigo, kenjougo, teineigo), and counters. The descriptions are concise without fluff words like 'learn' or 'explore'. CEFR progression is clear from basic greetings through to advanced pragmatics. It includes essential vocabulary themes (food, transport, health, technology) and communication scenarios (phone calls, emails, complaints). No culture, career, or exam prep chapters. The granularity is excellent - separating related concepts appropriately while maintaining logical flow.

Model F provides 64 well-organized chapters with excellent coverage of Japanese-specific elements. Hiragana and katakana are properly separated with detailed descriptions. Kanji coverage includes radicals and on/kun readings. Grammar progression is solid with all verb forms, particles, honorifics (keigo basic and advanced), and conditionals covered. Descriptions are generally concise, though some like 'Refinamento e Domínio Total' are slightly vague. Good vocabulary themes (health, technology, education) and communication scenarios. CEFR progression is clear. One minor issue: the final chapter 'Refinamento e Domínio Total' could be seen as somewhat of a capstone, though it does specify 'estruturas difíceis' making it content-focused.

Model A offers 66 comprehensive chapters with strong Japanese-specific coverage. Writing systems are combined into one chapter which is less ideal than separation. Kanji is covered at three levels (basic, intermediate, advanced). Grammar coverage is thorough: particles, all verb forms, passives, causatives, honorifics (separate chapters for 尊敬語 and 謙譲語), and conditionals. Descriptions are concise and to the point. Good vocabulary themes and communication scenarios. CEFR progression is evident. Minor weaknesses: combining all writing systems in one chapter, and the final chapter 'Refinamento e Maestria' is somewhat vague. Overall very solid.

Model E has 60 chapters with good coverage. Writing systems have dedicated chapters with kanji split into three levels. Strong grammar coverage including particles, verb forms, passives, causatives, honorifics, and conditionals. Descriptions are mostly concise. Good vocabulary themes. However, some descriptions use slightly fluffy language ('fundamentos', 'domínio'), and the progression could be cleaner in places. The keigo coverage is good with fundamentos and advanced chapters. Some chapters like 'Competência pragmática e estilo nativo' are somewhat vague.

Model H provides 97 chapters with detailed coverage. Hiragana and katakana are properly separated. Strong kanji coverage across multiple levels (N5, N4, N3, N2, N1 - though this JLPT reference could be seen as exam-prep adjacent). Grammar is comprehensive with all required forms. Honorifics are well covered (honorífica, humilde, polida). However, there are issues: multiple 'Padrões Gramaticais N2/N1' chapters explicitly reference JLPT levels which violates the no-exam-prep rule. Some chapters like 'Linguagem Jornalística' and 'Registro Literário' border on media/literature. Descriptions are generally concise.

Model G has 53 chapters covering Japanese essentials. Hiragana and katakana are separate. Kanji has one 'Fundamentos' chapter which is limited. Grammar coverage is good but less detailed than top models. Honorifics are split into sonkeigo and kenjougo. Descriptions are concise. The chapter 'Sociedade e Atualidades' could be seen as bordering on non-content domain. Coverage feels somewhat abbreviated at higher levels. Good CEFR progression but less comprehensive than top models.

Model C provides 44 chapters which is somewhat limited. Hiragana and katakana are properly separated, but kanji coverage is spread across only 4 chapters. Grammar coverage includes main verb forms, passives, causatives, keigo. Descriptions are concise. However, the curriculum feels abbreviated - only 44 chapters to cover A1-C2 means many topics are condensed. Some chapters combine multiple concepts that might benefit from separation. CEFR progression is present but compressed.

Model B has 64 chapters but with some quality issues. Writing systems are well separated with hiragana, katakana, and multiple kanji chapters. However, there are errors: 'tashikemasu' in 'Futuro e Intenções' appears to be incorrect Japanese. 'Forma Reflexiva' mentions 'reflexiva e recíprocas' but Japanese doesn't have a reflexive voice in the same way. Some descriptions are vague or contain odd terminology. 'Inchoativo e Movimento' uses unusual grammatical terminology. Kanji chapters are numerous but some descriptions lack detail. Grammar coverage is present but organization could be clearer.

Model D is the strongest output. It offers the most comprehensive and granular curriculum, breaking down the language into logical linguistic components (e.g., distinguishing between different conditional forms and specific writing system aspects). It strictly adheres to all negative constraints, successfully avoiding skill-based or culture-only chapters while ensuring the topics (like 'Classroom Instructions' or 'E-mails') remain within the content domain of communication scenarios and vocabulary. The Portuguese phrasing is natural and precise.

Model F is excellent and very close to Model D in quality. It uses precise linguistic terminology (e.g., giongo/gitaigo, sonkeigo/kenjogo) in the descriptions and maintains a strong progression from A1 to C2. It covers advanced pragmatics well. It is slightly less granular in the early stages compared to Model D but is otherwise a top-tier response.

Model A provides a solid, logical curriculum that follows all instructions. The titles and descriptions are concise and clear. The progression is appropriate for CEFR. While it lacks the impressive granular depth of Models D and F, it is a completely valid and high-quality response with no major flaws.

Model G offers a good curriculum with a clear progression. It covers the necessary grammar and vocabulary themes well. It includes interesting advanced topics like 'Formal Written Style'. It is slightly more generic in its intermediate section compared to the top models, but adheres well to the constraints.

Model C follows the instructions and constraints well. However, it is somewhat sparse compared to the others, containing fewer chapters. While the content is correct, the granularity is lower, potentially rushing through some complex topics.

Model E is generally good but loses points for including a chapter on 'Strategies for translation'. Translation is typically considered a specific skill or separate discipline rather than a core language acquisition content domain for a general curriculum. Otherwise, the progression and content are decent.

Model B contains a significant hallucination or error in Chapter 27 ('tashikemasu' for future plans, which is not a standard verb form for this context, likely confusing 'tashikameru' or another word). Additionally, the first chapter title is slightly redundant. These quality control issues rank it lower.

Model H explicitly structures the curriculum around JLPT levels (N5, N4, N3, etc.) in the titles and descriptions. This directly violates the instruction to follow CEFR progression and the negative constraint against proficiency exam preparation chapters. While the content itself is extensive, the framing contradicts the prompt's specific structural requirements.

Melhor aderência geral: capítulos exclusivamente de domínio (gramática/vocabulário/cenários), forte cobertura de gramática japonesa (partículas, te/teiru, condicionais, passiva/causativa, keigo, contadores, modalidade, coesão), e capítulos dedicados e bem segmentados para hiragana/katakana/kanji. Progressão implícita de básico a muito avançado (compatível com A1→C2) sem cair em cultura, exames ou carreira. Pequeno ponto de atenção: “Sala de Aula e Instruções” e “Gestão de Conversa” são cenários/funcões comunicativas aceitáveis, não capítulos de habilidade, então ok.

Muito bom: cobre escrita (hiragana/katakana + kanji essenciais e avançado), gramática central e avançada (partículas, formas verbais, condicionais, voz, keigo, modalidade) e vários temas/cenários. Progressão bem escalonada. Peca levemente por incluir “frases de sala de aula” e um capítulo final de “Revisão integrada…”, que tende a ser capítulo de habilidade/metacapítulo (proibido).

Bom equilíbrio entre escrita (hiragana/katakana + 3 blocos de kanji), gramática (partículas, te, condicionais, potencial, passiva/causativa, keigo, nominalização) e temas. Progressão razoável até avançado. Falhas: não há capítulo dedicado só a partículas (elas aparecem diluídas), e inclui “Kanji … encontrados em literatura”, tangenciando mídia/literatura (ainda que como domínio lexical/escrita).

Cobertura sólida de gramática e progressão para avançado (keigo, passiva/causativa, modalidade, estilo escrito, clássica no moderno) e inclui hiragana/katakana e um capítulo de kanji. Porém, kanji fica pouco desenvolvido (sem progressão em vários capítulos) e há poucos temas de vocabulário/cenários. Alguns títulos (“Provérbios tradicionais… enraizados na cultura”) encostam em cultura, embora como expressões linguísticas.

Abrangente e bem organizado, com capítulos dedicados aos três sistemas de escrita e boa gramática (partículas, formas verbais, voz, condicionais, discurso relatado, keigo) + muitos temas. Problemas relevantes: inclui capítulos profissionais/carreira (“formação de vocabulário… profissional”, “Trabalho e ocupações”, “Correspondência formal e-mails profissionais”), o que viola a restrição. Também há “Estratégias de fluência…”, que é mais skill-based/metacomunicativo.

Muito conteúdo e boa cobertura gramatical e temática, com kanji intermediário/avançado e keigo. Porém viola diretamente: inclui capítulo de carreira (“Trabalho e Profissões”) e também “Linguagem Formal de Serviço” com viés de atendimento/comercial (muito próximo de linguagem profissional). Além disso, o capítulo “Sistemas de Escrita” não é dedicado por sistema (a exigência pede capítulos dedicados para hiragana/katakana/kanji).

Cobertura ampla, mas várias violações: usa progressão por JLPT/N-level explicitamente (proibido: preparação/menção a exames), inclui “linguagem de negócios básica” e “e-mails profissionais” (carreira). Também tem capítulos que soam como habilidades/produção (“Narrativa Pessoal”, ok como cenário; mas a estrutura geral fica muito atrelada a exames). Ainda assim tem capítulos dedicados a escrita e boa gramática.

Tem capítulos dedicados a hiragana/katakana/kanji e cobre bastante gramática, mas há problemas grandes: inclui “Trabalho e Profissões” (carreira) e vários itens com baixa qualidade/erros (“tashikemasu” não é forma padrão; misturas estranhas como ‘iru e koto ga arimasu’ para futuro). Também traz “Voz Reflexiva”, categoria pouco padrão no japonês, e a progressão CEFR não fica clara (muito listado/heterogêneo).
